title: How to Make Clamato Juice From Scratch: It's...
text:
Combine tomato juice, clam juice, Worcestershire sauce, Tabasco sauce, black pepper and and stir.Add more Worcestershire sauce, Tabasco sauce and/or black pepper if desired. 
Consider adding a dash of Montreal steak seasoning to the juice or save it to use as a glass rimmer when serving the finished product. Learn how to rim a glass . It enhances overall savoriness and visual appreciation of the drink. 
Garnish individual servings with one celery stalk and a lemon or lime wedge and serve alcohol-free or use the clamato juice to make Bloody Caesar cocktails . 
Get creative and dazzle dinner guests with different drink garnishes like cocktail shrimps on a stick or a giant one hanging off the glass rim. I've seen everything from olives and hot peppers to bacon and crab legs topping Bloody Caesars. 
Clamato Juice: Invented in Canada 
Both the Bloody Caesar and clamato juice were invented at the same time by the same man in Canada in 1969. Or so the story goes. 
On one fine day in the late '60s, the Calgary Inn (now the Westin Hotel) asked Montenegrin bartender Walter Chell to create a cocktail to celebrate the grand opening of the inn's new Italian restaurant, Marco's. 
Chell, inspired by his allegedly favorite dish spaghetti vongole, obliged after months of experimentation. 
According to Chell's granddaughter Sheena Parker , Chell "is Italian and a fantastic cook and came up with a concoction of mixing clam juice with tomato juice and Worcestershire sauce, Tabasco and vodka and because of his Italian ancestry, decided to call it Caesar," she said, adding, "there was a British man at the bar at the time and he said, 'That's a bloody good Caesar', and that's where he came up with the Bloody Caesar." 
Inventor of clamato juice, yes. However, The Food Network claims Chell wasn't the first one to toy with the concept of clams in a drink. But he certainly perfected it.
